you can have more exotic indices.
Even with standard integer coordinates, the key difference is that the non-set entries are not structural zeros, they are undefined, for example if you have x[i in 1:5, j in i:5], x[3, 2] would error because it doesn't exist

text: I have a use-case that I have been thinking about for quite some time now. I do computer vision and compute projections of object points into images. I want to have a visibility matrix as the result, where each entry contains the pixel position of a point projected into the image if it is visible or nothing if it is not. Here, zero is a valid value, so having a real nothing and using a sparse data structure is important.
